titleStmt.title: Aristotle's legacy: or, his golden cabinet of secrets opened. In five treatices 1. The wheel of fortune. 2. The art of Palmestry. 3. A treatise of moles 4. The interpreter of dreams. 5. Observations on fortunate and unfortunate days. With many other secrets and experiments, never before published. To which is added, a compleat book of riddles. 1. The fortune teller, or knowledge of good & bad fortune, ... 7. Also the best and most powerful receipt for making love powder. To which are added twenty merry and pleasant riddles, with their solutions or explanations: the whole illustrated throughout with curious cuts, proper to each particular: being the best, most exact, and accomplished book of this nature.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2012-06 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images

div.p: Ari≈øtotle's Legacy: OR, HIS Golden CABINET of Secrets Opened. IN Five Treatices.

list.item: 5. Ob≈øervations on Fortunate and Unfortunate days.

div.p: With many other Secrets and Experiments, never before Publi≈øhed. To which is Added, A Compleat Book of RIDDLES.

1. The fortune-teller, or Knowledge of good & bad fortune, by throwing the Dice on the Wheel of Fortune. 2. By Palme≈øtry, as the Lines or Marks in the Hand. 3. By Phi≈øognomy, or the ≈øeveral parts of the Face, and Head; as Eyes, No≈øe, Chin, Hair, &c. By Metopo≈øcopy, as the ≈øeveral Lines and Marks in the Forehead, and other parts of the Face: With Marks, and ≈øacred Characters, and all other matters, relating to long or ≈øhort life, Love, Bu≈øine≈øs: The Humours and Di≈øpo≈øitions of the Partys, and how they are Enclin'd. 4. A Treati≈øe of Moles, and their ≈øignifications, on the Face, or any part of the Body. The like of Dreams and their interpretation; more exact than ever. 5. Ob≈øervations on Valentines day, St. Agnes day, and upon the fir≈øt hearing the Cuckoo, as they particularly relate to Love and Marriage: by which a Maid or Widdow may know whether her ≈øweet-heart be true or fal≈øe, in earne≈øt or in je≈øt; when Married, and if Fortunate or Unfortunate, in Wedlock. 6. To know whether a pure Virgin or not: How to make an Enchanted Ring, to make any who wears it, to fall in love with you. 7. Al≈øo the be≈øt and mo≈øt powerful Receipt for making Love Powder. To which are Added twenty Merry and Plea≈øant Riddles, with their Solutions or Explanations: The whole illu≈øtrated throughout with Curious Cuts, proper to each particular: Being the be≈øt, mo≈øt exact, and accompli≈øhed Book of this Nature.
Tran≈ølated into Engli≈øh by Dr. Borman, Student in A≈øtrology.
Licen≈øed according to Order.
Printed for J. Blare, at the Looking-Gla≈øs on London-Bridge.

div.head: OF THE Wheel of Fortune.

figure.figDesc: dice faces surrounded by a circle with thirty sequentially numbered divisions, a sun, a new and a full moon, a man, a woman, a kissing couple, and a necklace(?)

div.p:
HERE you mu≈øt Throw to know your FORTUNE, with two Dice; and, as the Number comes up, go to the Figure of Men for Men; and that of Women for Women: Suppo≈øe (for Example) you throw two Duces, go to Number Four, and there you'll find the≈øe words:
You throw unluckily, ≈øhe that You wou'd Wid,
∆≤nto another gives her Maiden-head.
And ≈øo proceed in any other throw, and you will find your fortune; and the be≈øt Luck comes, throwing in the New or full of the Moon; and when you have thrown, you mu≈øt not throw again.

div.head: How to know Good or Bad Fortune to Men, in Love Matters and Bu≈øine≈øs, by Changes on the Dice, in the Wheel of Fortune.

lg.l: SHE will be brown, and of a middle Age;
A brisk and lively Wench, I will engage:
But in her love, with others you ≈øhall ≈øhare,
yet of the main Chance, ≈øhe will have a care.
Di≈øpair not yet, though you in love were cro≈øt;
A Fortune comes, Redeeming what is lo≈øt;
fair ≈øhe will be, and in her you will find,
Though not much wealth, contentment of the mind.
You throw unlucky; ≈øhe that you wou'd Wed,
∆≤nto another gives her Maiden head;
And if you have her, you will be much cro≈øt,
She's peevi≈øh, proud, and will be better lo≈øt.
Lament no more for „Äà‚óä„Äâ that you does ≈ølight,
The next Y ‚Ä¢ u Court, will be ‚Ä¶ prove, and kind;
this (if pur≈øu'd) will ≈øtill but vex your mind.
A luckey throw, the bu≈øine≈øs that's in hand,
You ≈øhall go thro' with, and much wealth command,
The Lucky Planet Reign'd, when you begun it,
And you had ≈øtill liv'd poor, had you not done it.
O for a Jovial Dame your Bed's de≈øign'd;
She ll Guild your Fortune, b her being kind;
She will not ≈øpend, but thrive by her Amours;
And bring (with Horns) much plenty to your ≈øtores.
think once again, e'er you take it in hand;
You do pur≈øue what you don't under≈øtand:
A Maid you think her, but the Stars ≈øay nay;
You'll be a Father on your Wedding-day.
No more be fearful, it is ≈øo decreed,
You mu≈øt go on, and in your love ≈øucceed;
What though you powerful Rivals have at la≈øt,
You ≈øhall prevail, though'twill not be in ha≈øt.
Believe not what is ≈øaid, it is not true,
Tho≈øe that per≈øwade it are no friends to you;
They wou'd break off the Match; that is their aim,
She hone≈øt is, and free from ≈øuch a blame.
Con≈øider well, this is a luckey throw,
If your neglecting does not make it low;
Pur≈øue your love, or you'll be Circumvented;
And then your ≈øloath will be in vain repented.
Two Sizes; ah! what ≈øhall I ≈øay of this?
I fear you will your Expectation mi≈øs:
However, give not o'er, but love pur≈øue,
The blank may turn to them, the Prize to you.

div.head:
Good or bad Fortune „Äà‚óä„Äâ
‚Ä¶ en on the Chance of the Dice, in Love and Bu≈øine≈øs, by „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Wheel of Fortune.

lg.l: O Me, a Red-Hair'd Man will be your lot;
But he to plea≈øe You, has a good thing got;
You Children will have many, and much plea≈øure,
Then be content without a World of trea≈øure.
Well thrown I vow, you now will catch the Fi≈øh,
For which you Angle, and ≈øo long did wi≈øh;
He ≈øees his Error, and he will be kind;
And in your Change, you'll much contentment find.
Leave off your whining; ca≈øt away your fears;
The day comes on, you will dry up Your tears:
'twas your own fault that made you ≈øo long ≈øtay;
You ≈øee what's got, by fooli≈øh ≈øaying nay.
Lay all Your Scruples by, for this is he,
That mu≈øt (in ≈øpight of all) Your Husband be;
What though he is not lovely to the ≈øight,
He'll give you (in the Dark) Your hearts delight.
Ah me! how Cro≈øs a Throw is this? you will not gain
The Man you ≈øeek, though you pur≈øue with pain;
He's a deceiver, and already Wedd;
He'll leave you when he's Cropt your Maiden-head.
Well may you blu≈øh, You will not Childle≈øs die,
Your too ≈øoon yielding, made him fal≈øe to prove;
Had You been coy, you had entail'd his Love.
This Ca≈øt (if you are wi≈øe) does promi≈øe you,
You'll ≈øoon be Woo'd by one that's Cha≈øt and True;
But manage well your bu≈øine≈øs, le≈øt you lo≈øe,
What (to your content) you ought to Choo≈øe.
What you have took in hand, does promi≈øe well,
And happie it will be, the Stars fore-tell;
Neglect not then the vi≈øits that are made,
Le≈øt (by your folly) your good Luck's betray'd.
You've not ≈ølay'd too long, this is the time,
Fortune comes to you in her gawdy prime;
She flings her favours on you now at la≈øt,
It flowing comes, when you fear'd it was pa≈øt.
Hit upon hit, two comes at once to Wooe,
But take the lea≈øt, the bigge≈øt will not do;
He will be Kinde≈øt, and mo≈øt Wealthy prove;
The other not; he has been oft in love.
Duce take it; what a ≈øtrange turn up is here?
You have your ≈øelf been too turn'd up I fear:
It ≈øays you are with-Child, and yet I gather,
E're the boy comes, you'll get a kind Father.

div.head: The whole Art of Palme≈øtry, or telling Fortunes by the Hand; and fir≈øt of the Hand to be cho≈øen, and the Planets and Signs Governing the parts of it.

figure.figDesc: the palm of a right hand, with several major lines noted and its parts linked to planetary and zodiacal signs

div.p:
BEfore I proceed to particular Prognosticks (in Chiromancy or Palme≈øtry) I mu≈øt tell you the Left hand is the mo≈øt proper to be impected, becau≈øe the Heart and Brain has the greater Influence on it; and do this when the Body is in a good Temper, not di≈øturb'd by Pa≈ø≈øions, or over Eating or Drinking; for then the Lines will not appear full, nor in their natural colour: A Hand, when the Lines
are broken, or much worn by hard labour, cannot be well in≈øpected, to make a true Judgment.

As for the Planetary Rule in the Hand; Venus governs the Thumb, Jupiter the Fore-Finger, Saturn the longe≈øt or middle Finger, the Sun the third Finger, Mercury the little Finger, the Brawn of the Hand is governed by the Moon, and the Hollow or plain bp Mars, and ≈øo the little Mounts or Ri≈øings under each Finger, and the Ball of the Thumb, and the out-≈øide Brawn, are under the re≈øpective Planets, that Govern the Fingers, Thumb, &c.

div.head: The ≈øeveral lines of the Hand, by which a True Judgment (in telling Fortunes) mu≈øt be made.

figure.figDesc: the palm of a right hand, with several major lines and features noted

div.p:
THE mo≈øt ≈øignificant in Palme≈øtry, are thus de≈øcribed, viz. The Line of Life reaches from the Wre≈øt, almo≈øt to the Root of the Fore-Finger, the Table
Line is in the middle, or Table of the Hand, and in ≈øome Hands runs along the four Mounts, participating of the Influence, of the re≈øpective Planets Governing them; the middle line running cro≈øs the Hand, and ≈øometimes Obliquely it takes its beginning at the Ri≈øing of the Fore-Finger, near the line of life, ending at the Mount of the Moon. The line of the Brain, u≈øually called the Liver line, reaches to the Table line, making a Triangle, thus ‚ñµ. The Girdle of Venus begins near the Joynt of the little Finger, & ends between the fore-Finger, & middle-Finger; the line of Death, or great Misfortunes, when it appears plain, as a Counter-line to the line of life; and therefore is called its Si≈øter line, ending as it ends; the percu≈ø≈øion is between the Mount of Venus, and that of the Moon; the Wri≈øt lines, commonly called Re≈øcetta, are no other than tho≈øe Joynts that part the Hand.

div.head: Fortune, Good or Bad, known by the Lines, and other Marks and Characters, in the Hands of Men, Women, and Children.

figure.figDesc: two right hand palms, marked by various lines, shapes, and symbols

div.p:
HAving given you an in≈øpection of the Planets governing th ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ , and of the Lines of the Hand, I come now to give you a true Judgm ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
upon them, as to Good or Bad Fortune, thereby ≈øignified to the Party, as they are more or le≈øs Significant in them≈øelves, or what other matters attend them.

When the Line of Life is fair, well proportioned, coloured, and di≈øpo≈øed, it denotes a quiet and peaceable Life, fortunate, and Healthful; but if Cro≈ø≈øes or Stars happen on it, the contrary is threatned: if a double Line of life appear, it promi≈øes long Life, advancement to Honour, and ≈øucce≈øs in weighty Affairs in Men, in Women much Love, encrea≈øe of Children, and great Felicity in Marriage Three Stars appearing in this Line, it threatens the party ≈øhall fall into many Di≈øgraces and troubles by envie and fal≈øehood. Three Cro≈ø≈øes, appearing, denotes misfortunes in Love, and much mi≈øchief thereby; when Lines come from the mount of Venus, and cut the Line of Life, it denotes the Party Unfortunate in Love or Bu≈øine≈øs, and threatens him or her with ≈øudden Death: if near the Ligament of the Thumb, a Woman have two Cro≈øes, they Cro≈ø≈øing the upper part of the Line of Life, it denotes her to be Uncha≈øt, very immode≈øt, and Lu≈øtful, if the Line of Life cro≈øs or twi≈øt with the table-line, then Honour and Riches are promi≈øed together, with the love and Favour of Great Ones: if the table-line be broad, and of a lively colour, it ≈øhews health, a contented mind, and the party Couragious and Succe≈øsful: if there be Cro≈ø≈øes in the table-Line, towards the little finger, they denote the party ≈øubject to much Sickne≈øs, and often troubled in Mind: if this Line he forked at the End, extending towards the mount of Jupiter, it denotes the party ≈øhall get Riches; but by Fraud and Deceit, be full of Doubts, Fears, and Jealou≈øies, and lead a weary≈øom Life: if this table-line be crooked, it denotes the party in danger of Life, by ≈øome Furious bea≈øt, or Per≈øon Di≈øtracted, or di≈øordered by drinking: if there be two Cro≈ø≈øes upon the table-line, it promi≈øes promotion by Learning: if on this line three ≈øtops; as thus... be found, they denote the Party Prud ‚Ä¢ nt, and ri≈øing to great preferment, by good conduct, in managing weighty Affai ‚Ä¢ s: in the middle or Natural Line, which above the re≈øt has a Communication with the Vital Parts, has any Cro≈ø≈øes on it; it denotes Riches to the Party; but that he or ≈øhe is of a covetous ≈øordid temper.
As many Lines as are between the middle line, and the Thumb-line; denote to ≈øome, many Sickne≈ø≈øes, and Ca≈øualties; and yet the party e≈øcape with life.

If a Cro≈øs branch from the Table-Line it denotes the party much addicted to Devotion, virtuou≈øly ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ clined, and ri≈øing thereby to great promotion. The Middle-line cutting in two, and ≈øoon di≈øcontinuing, of a pale colour; denotes the di≈øplea≈øure of princes, and by offending them, Death, or ≈øharp impri≈øonment will en≈øue: if the Line called the Girdle of Venus, happen to be Di≈ø≈øected, or divided near the Fore-Finger, it denotes the party much given to Lu≈øtful de≈øires, that will prove Ruinous in the End: if the Sanctions be under the Middle finger, it endangers life, by evil cour≈øes taken, to ≈øatisfie unlawful plea≈øure.

div.head: Sacred Characters, Marks, or Letters in the Hand, Relating to good or bad Fortune, in Men, Women, or Children.
div.p:
THere are many letters often formed in the hand, called, Sacred Characters; and of the≈øe I ≈øhall ≈øpeak briefly, as they Relate to good or bad Fortune; an A found between the Mount of the Moon, and the hollow of the hand, denotes
Sickne≈øs and Lo≈ø≈øes; but if it appears towards the Mount of Venus, it denotes happy Marriages, Joy, and Pro≈øperity: if a T be on the Mount of Venus, it denotes ≈øucce≈øs in love Affairs; but if it comes ≈øo low as to cut the line of life, then it denotes cro≈ø≈øes and misfortunes in love, and much mi≈øchief: A P on the ball of
the palm of a right hand, its lines and features marked by letters and numbers the Thumb denotes Honour and Preferment; a Q in the Angle or Hollow, many Marriages: an X Vexation and Trouble.

div.head: Phi≈øognomy, or good and bad ‚Ä¢ ortune, told by the Lines of the ‚Ä¢ ace; and fir≈øt of the Planets, and governing Signs.
Good or Bad Fortune known by the Eyes, No≈øe Mouth, Ears, &c. of Men or Women.
div.p:
LArge Eyes, denotes the party ≈øtout and Couragious, but Deceitful, and of a Quarrel≈øome humour. Eyes party colour, denotes a Woman much given
a male and a female face with exaggerated forehead lines to Love, but in≈øtable and Uncon≈øtant. Greeni≈øh little Eyes, ≈øtanding inward, denotes wi≈ødom and Councils, Fortunate in ≈øucce≈øs, &c. A large No≈øe, much
hanging down, denotes Covetou≈øne≈øs. A round No≈øe at the extremitys „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈ømall No≈øtrils, denotes, in a Man Pride and incredulity; in a Woman, much given to Love and lu≈øt. A red No≈øe, naturally ≈øo, denotes a Contentious Turbulent, and Quarrel≈øome Per≈øon If in a female the Gri≈øtle of the No≈øe ≈øeem to part from the Bone‚ñ™ or to be dinted at the end, ≈øhe hath (undoubtedly) lo≈øt her Virginity. A great Mouth, ≈øtanding un≈øeemly wide, denotes the party fooli≈øh, but a great babler, and Devulger of fal≈øe ≈øtorys, delighting to make Mi≈øchief. A little Mouth, well proportioned, denotes the party wi≈øe, peac ‚Ä¢ able, loving and cha≈øt. The Ears large and thick, denotes a defect in Memory, and fooli≈øh: little and thin the contrary: A fle≈øhy Face denotes a merry chearful per≈øon: A thin lean one, a wi≈øe, but malicious, and covetous Per≈øon.

div.head: Good or bad Fortune known by the Hair, Chin, and Eye-brows, of Man or Woman.
div.p:
THE Hair of the Head thick and ≈øoft, denotes a man of an Affable mild Temper. Curled, har≈øh black hair, denotes the Party boi≈øterous, rough, and much given to anger. Golden hair, denotes the party treac ‚Ä¢ erous, and covetous; Red Hair, enclining to black, wi≈øe, but crafty and ≈øubtil in mi≈øchief. A Cha≈øenut coloured hair, ≈øignifies the party of fair condition, mild, & well di≈øpo≈øed
two faces with exaggerated forehead lines Sudden baldne≈øs in youth, denotes poverty. A long Chin, denotes a woman turbulent and vexatious; and a Man letcherous and fooli≈øh. A little Chin, denotes malice, fraud, and de≈øpight: A round Chin, denotes a Man effeminate, yet haughty and proud. A ≈øquare Chin denotes great courage, and agility of Body; A dimpled Chin, roundi≈øh, or a little oval, denotes the party loving, affable, and of a good temper. A lean wrinkled Chin, denotes the party unfit for Marriage Dutys. Fine little Eye-brows, denotes affability, love, and con≈øtancy; bending and over hanging Brows, the contrary: Eye-brows ≈øhort and narrow, denotes the Party of a ≈øoft plyable Temper. Eye-lids long, with long-hair, denotes the party clowni≈øh, and morro≈øs, yet of great ability of parts.

div.head: „Äà‚óä„Äâ and Bad Fortune known by the Li ‚Ä¢ es, Marks, and other Significations in the Foreh ‚Ä¢ ad, and other parts of the Faces of Men ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d Women.
div.p:
LInes in the Face or Fore-head, are exceeding ≈øignificant, in matter of Fortune. Three ≈øtraight Lines, without any Section or Divi≈øion, denotes the Party very pro≈øperous A Circle in the Line that pa≈ø≈øes crooked, through the Foreh ‚Ä¢ ad, denotes lo≈øs, and much trouble and di≈øgrace. A crooked line between two
three faces with exaggerated forehead lines ≈øtraight Lines, denotes the party fortunate. A crooked Line, with a ≈øtraight line above it, denotes the party ≈øhall be Rich, but it will be gained by fraud and over-reaching. Two lines cro≈ø≈øing the fore-head, wavering in and out thus ‚ôí th ‚Ä¢ eatens the party to be in peril of life, by water. Two lines bending arch-wi≈øe over the E ‚Ä¢ e-brows; one of them cro≈ø≈øed with a cro≈øs, or three ≈øhort lines in a length, in the extremity of the fore-head, denotes the party to be good Natured, and to get Riches by Marriages. A cro≈øs directly in the middle of the fore-head, with ≈ø ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ing lines aboue it, threatens the party with Violent death: four half lines, or lines that are not met in the middle of the fore-head, with a full line over them, cro≈ø≈øed by two Sections, denotes lo≈øs and affliction. A Star in the forehead, denotes great preferment.

div.head: Dreams, as they tend to good or bad Fortune, with their interpretations.
div.p: DReam, (though ≈øome very ignorant in ≈øuch rare mi≈øterys, have ≈ølighted them) are ‚Ä¢ by the ‚Ä¢ ages, and wi≈øe men of all Ages very ≈øignificant; and that the S ‚Ä¢ ul, wh ‚Ä¢ n the B ‚Ä¢ dy Repo≈øes, being di≈øcumbred from gro≈øs and weighty Cares; for the fl ‚Ä¢ ≈øh (by this My≈øterious way) Confabulates, or Conver≈øes with Spirits or Angels, who bring to its Knowledge, future Events, very ≈øtrange and wonderful as in Scripture we find it in Pharoahs, Nebuch ‚Ä¢ dnezzers, and others Dreams, that exactly come to pa≈øs, according to their Interpretation: But not to prolong the Matter, I proceed (by the Rules of Art) to give the interpretation of Dreams.

To Dream one is flying in the Air, promi≈øes ha≈øty news, To Dream one Swims
with plea≈øures in a to≈ø≈øing water, denotes overcoming ≈øome difficult matter you have in hand. To Dream you hear Birds Sing Mellodiou≈øly, betokens Joy, and to the Sick Recovery. To Dream one pre≈øents you with a Gold Ring, and puls it on your Finger, fore≈øhews ≈øpeedy Marriage. To Dream you are dancing in Jolly
a group of people pointing at two floating heads? Company, ≈øignifies mu ‚Ä¢ h Joy and mirth. To dream ≈øome Furious Bea≈øt pur≈øues, and you cannot avoid it, betokens your Enemys will prevail again≈øt you. To dream you are ≈øtung or bitten by ‚Ä¢ erpents or in≈øects, denotes mi≈øchief, to come from malicious and private Enemys. To dream you meet a Lyon and he fawns on you denotes the Favour of great ones To dream one is in a Field of ≈øtanding Corn, denotes pro≈øperity. To dream you meet a black Coffin, with Mourners, denotes the death of ≈øome Friend. To dream one fights, & overc ‚Ä¢ mes, denotes ≈øucce≈øs in what you are contending for, or e≈øcap ‚Ä¢ ing dangers that threaten you. To dream you are wa≈øhing your hands, and the di ‚Ä¢ t comes clean off, ≈øignifies you ≈øhall perform ≈øome great Enterprize. To dream a Friend is dead, denotes he or ≈øhe is well. To dream your Eyes or Teeth fall out, denotes, Sickne≈øs, or death of Children, or ≈øome intimate friend, or near Relation. To dream ones ≈øhooes falls off, or are old & torn, denotes poverty and di≈øtre≈øs To dream a hor≈øe runs away with you, denotes unexpected bu≈øine≈øs, not plea≈øing to you. To dream a Gold Ring breaks, and falls from your finger, denotes the lo≈øs of a Lover, or ≈øome dear Friend. To dream you are ≈øailing in a Calm, denotes a peaceable Life; but ≈øuddenly overtaken in a Storm, trouble and affliction. To dream of Courting a beautiful Woman, betokens Cro≈ø≈øes and Vexation. To dream you put on fine Cloaths, denotes preferment. To dream you hunt a Hare, but cannot ta ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ her, denotes the lo≈øs of ≈øome matter you are in pur≈øuit of. To Dream
you endeavour to fly, and cannot,
a giant devil or satyr with a broom and candle dancing inside a circle, surrounded by many dancing people betokens Impri≈øonment & Re≈øtraints. A Virgin Dreaming ≈øhe is putting on New Garments, denotes an alteration of her condition, by Marriage, to dream of lighted tapors, denotes the party ≈øhall be happy in many friends. To Dream of the Chattering of Swallows, denotes Sickne≈øs, or other Infirmitys to fall, For a barren woman to Dream ≈øhe pro≈øtitutes her ≈øelf with one of her own Sex, denotes ≈øhe ≈øhall conceive; but to a Child-bearing Woman, it is Mi≈øcarriage. To dream you ≈øee great fires, is anger or ≈øickne≈øs: For lovers To dream they fall out, denotes con≈øtancy, and affection: to dream one receives a Letter, denotes love & con≈øtancy, or that the party ≈øhall have ≈øatisfaction in what he de≈øires: to dream one puts on new white Gloves, denotes the Marriage of Friends; but black ones their Death. For a Woman to Dream ≈øhe is with Child, De ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es Sorrow, and hard Labour; but to dream ≈øhe is delivered, the contrary. To dream you ≈øee an withered tree, ≈øprouting out, denotes Chilldren in old age: to dream you are ca≈øt away in a Ship-wrack, denotes great lo≈ø≈øes in goods or e≈øtate: to dream you ≈øee a ≈ømall ≈øpring, grow into a great lake, denotes encrea≈øe of Riches: to dream of Ribbons, & gay Plumes of Feathers denotes amendment of Fortune.

div.head: Other Advantagious ways particularly Relating to Love and Marriage, Approved and Succe≈øsful.

figure.figDesc: a man and woman kiss as another man looks on

div.head: On Valentine's Day.
div.p: TAke two Bay leaves, ≈øprinkle them with Ro≈øe-water; the Evening of this day, lay them a-cro≈øs under your pillow, when you go to bed, putting on a clean ≈øhift, and turning it the wrong ≈øide outwards; and lying down, ≈øay, the≈øe words ≈øoftly to your ≈øelf.

q.l: Good Valentine be kind to me,
In Dreams let me my true Love ≈øee:

div.p: So cro≈ø≈øing your legs, and go to ≈øleep as ≈øoon as you can, you will ≈øee (in a Dream) the party you are to Marry, come to your bed-≈øide, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d offer you all mode≈øt Kindne≈øs, to your ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ eat Contentment.

div.head: On St. Agne's day.
div.p:
Take a Sprigg of Ro≈øemary, and another of Time, ≈øprinkle them with your
∆≤rine, thrice; and in the Evening of this day, put one into one ≈øhooe, and the other into the other; place your ≈øhooes on each ≈øide your beds head, and going to bed ≈øay ≈øoftly to your ≈øelf.

q.l: St. Agnes that's to Lovers kind,
Come ea≈øe the troubles of my mind.

div.p: Then take your re≈øt, having ≈øaid your prayers; when you are a≈øleep you will dream of your lover, and fancy you hear him talk to you of love, looking in the ≈øhooes, and attempting to put them on your Feet, with much kindne≈øs: If two are de≈øirous of you, they will both appear, and ≈øtrive who ≈øhall do you the be≈øt Offices, and the party who overcomes in this, is your lot; for you will perceive the other quickly vani≈øh, ≈øighing and much di≈øplea≈øed.

div.head: Love Ob≈øervations on fir≈øt hearing the Cuckoo.
div.p:
When you walk abroad (in the Spring) as ≈øoon as you hear the Cuckoo, ≈øit down on a bank, or any convenient place, and pull the Stocking from off your Right leg; and whil≈øt you are doing it, ≈øay:
May this to me
Now Luckey be. then look between your great toes, & you will find a hair which will ea≈øily come off; take it, & look well on it, & you will perceive it to be the colour the partys hair you de≈øire; wrap it up it a piece of paper, and keep it ten days carefully, if then it has not changed colour, the party loved will be con≈øtant, and you will obtain your de≈øire; but if it do, you are flattered, and will be deceived.

div.head: Signs of Love, and ≈øpeedy Marriage; or the contrary, by ≈øeeing or meeting divers ≈øorts of Creatures, fir≈øt in a morning.
div.p: THe≈øe Signs of love and marriage, have been greatly taken notice of in their exact ≈øucceeding according to the partys de≈øire.

If a Robin-Red-Bre≈øt come fluttering to your window, and ≈øing plea≈øantly, pearching near it, it denotes ≈øpeedy marriage to the party, and a merry contented life. If a hare ≈øta ‚Ä¶

div.head: To make an Enchanted Ring, to cau≈øe one to fall in love with you.
div.p: Get a hollow Ring, ≈øteep Goats hair taken from the Beard, ≈øteep it in the juice of Night Shade, or Wake Robin, an herb ≈øo called, pull it through the Ring, and whoever wears it, it ≈øhall cau≈øe them to fall in love with you.

div.head: to make the true Love Powder.
div.p: Take Ellicumpane, the ≈øeeds or flowers Viruine, and the berrys of Me≈øleto, beat them, when well dryed in an Oven, into a fine Powder, give it the party you de≈øign upon, a dram in a gla≈øs of wine, or other liquors, and it will work wonderful effects to your advantage.

div.head: Moles on the Face, their ≈øignification, as they relate to Good or Bad Fortune in Men, Women, and Children.
div.p:
MOles in the Face particularly, and tho≈øe in parts of the body, are very ≈øignificant as to good or bad Fortune. A Mole on on the left ≈øide of the forehead, denotes the party ≈øhall get Riches by tillage, building and planting. A mole on the right ≈øide of the forehead, promi≈øes happy contentment of life, a loving ≈øtate in matrimony, &c. A Mole in the middle of the forehead, denotes the party ≈øubject

fruitful in Children; but not extream long liv'd. A Mole on the right corner of the mouth, near the Jaw, promi≈øes happy days to either Sex, but on the left ≈øide unlawful Copulation, and much lo≈øs thereby: a mole on the middle of the upper lip, or on the chin, denotes ≈øucce≈øs in love; but no great fortune.

div.head: Good or Bad Fortune ≈øignified by Moles in the Bodyes of Men or Women, &c.

figure.figDesc: Adam and Eve and the serpent in the Garden of Eden

div.p:
A Mole on the right arm; denotes Riches and Honour to a man or woman, by great undertakings, and happy marriages: a mole on the left arm, under the wri≈øt, denotes the Party to be cro≈ø≈øed in his i≈ø≈øue, but that he ≈øhall attain riches: a mole on the arm-pit, ≈øignifies ≈øickne≈øs and hard≈øhip by travel: a mole on the right ≈øide, and upper part of the brea≈øt, denotes the party to encrea≈øe in wealth, by tillage, and other rural imployments: a Mole on the back enclining to the right ≈øide, denotes riches and honour, to be gained by the favour of great Men: a Mole on the upper part of the right ≈øide the belly, denotes to a Man good fortune in marriages; and to a Woman hopeful Children: a Mole on the left ≈øide the brea≈øt, threatens a man with di≈øgrace, & lo≈øs of friend≈øhip, a woman with poverty, neglect, and di≈øregard of her affairs: a Mole on the left ≈øide the belly, denotes indifferent good fortune to man or woman: a Mole on the groin, enclining to the right ≈øide of the loin,
a nude man and woman ≈øignifies pro≈øperity, and fortune to man or woman, by marriage, or other ways: a mole appearing on the right or left knee, denotes a per≈øon will advantage him≈øelf by travel into ≈øtrange Countrys: a mole on the calf of a man's Legg, denotes him exceeding lu≈øtful, and de≈øirous of other mens wives, endangering him≈øelf; and to a woman, lo≈øs of honour, not unde≈øervedly: a mole on the middle of the privy members, denotes great infirmitys, and a continuation of troubles to a man; but to a woman, to be beloved, and have many Children: a mole on the right ≈øide, ≈øomewhat above the lower part of the privy members, declares a man happy in womens love, and to gain much by marriage: A Mole on the right th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ near the huckle, denotes the party to grow rich, by rural affairs. Two Mol ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ an≈øwering equally on either ≈øide the Gullet, threatens untimely Death.

div.head: Curious Merry Riddles on ≈øundry matters, to pa≈øs away the time in harmle≈øs mirth, and witty Recreation.
Riddle 1.
div.l: Mo≈øt ≈øwift I am, and mo≈øt I pride,
When I ≈øubmit to others Guide;
In bloody Battels oft i'm ≈øeen;
Since time begun my Race has been.
div.p: Solution. It is a Hor≈øe and his Rider.

div.head: Riddle 2.
div.l: From earths deep womb, I fetch my trea≈øure,
That to Mankind affords much plea≈øure,
Without what is produc'd by me,
Nothing could live, but all mu≈øt dye.
div.p: Solution, It is a Fountain flowing with Water.

div.head: Riddle 3.

figure.figDesc: a person sitting in a chair reading a book

div.l: Though twenty-four I do contain,
They change to thou≈øands in the main;
Fair Ladys Court me, and di≈øpute
By me, although my ≈øelf am mute.
div.p: Solution. It is a Book, in which are but twenty-four Letters, though multiplied into Millions, and Read by ladies, out of which Arguments are rai≈øed, &c.

div.head: Riddle 4.
div.l: I in Kings Pallaces am ≈øeen.
And Ki≈øs the hand of King and Queen,
Sometimes I am, ≈øometimes i'm not,
Yet never im of men forgot:
I being near, they gather ≈øtore,
But being gone, earth's bare and poor.
div.p: Solution, This is a Flie that gets away before winter, and in ≈øpring or ≈øummer returns again.

div.head: Riddle 5.
div.l: Though low I am, yet I am fair,
Fine I adys me about them wear,
They Ki≈øs me, lay me in their Brea≈øt,
When Gallants are not half ≈øo ble≈øt.
div.p: Solution. It is a Pink, or July-Flower, much coveted by ladies.

div.head: Riddle 6.

figure.figDesc: a kneeling king is crowned by another figure

div.l: What Fortune gives I wear in ≈øtate,
A little thing does make me great;
All do admire me when I wear it,
Yet Cares attend all tho≈øe that bear it.
div.p: Solution, Is is a Crown on a King's Head.

div.head: Riddle 7.
div.l: When my beloved looks on me,
Then I always cheerful be;
But when it cea≈øes to do ≈øo,
Drawn in and veil'd, I mournful grow.
div.p: Solution, It is a Marigold, opening in the morning to the Suns ri≈øing, but clo≈øes at its ≈øetting.

div.head: Riddle 8.
div.l: Wi≈øe≈øt of Creatures Men me call,
Though many times they ≈øeek my fall,
But when they mo≈øt do Envy me,
I then fare be≈øt and fatte≈øt be.
div.p: Solution, It is a Fox, who, as the old Proverb is, the more he is cur≈øt, the better he fares.

div.head: Riddle 9.

figure.figDesc: an elephant with a castle on its back

div.l: I am e≈øteem'd, though i'm not fair,
Buildings upon my back I bear,
in War I terrible am known,
And a whole Squardron have o'erthrown.
div.p: Solution, It is an Elephant, with a Ca≈øtle on his back.

div.head: Riddle 10.
div.l: What all con≈øumes, be≈øt plea≈øes me,
I court that from which others flee;
Strange thing to tell, unhurt I lie
And thrive, where all things el≈øe would die.
div.p: Solution, it is a Salamander bred by a violent heat, and living in fire.

div.head: Riddle 11.
div.l: Both Bird and Bea≈øt I am together,
Yet ≈øeperated I am neither,
With terror I o're Citys fly,
And by my fury many dye.
div.p: Solution, it is a Griffin, the fore part like an Eagle, and the hinder part like a Lyon.

div.head: Riddle 12.
div.l: When I my White Robes have put on,
My friends from me then all are gone,
But when in Green I do appear,
They ha≈øte with plea≈øure to draw near.
div.p: Solution, it is a Garden, the white Robes is its covering with Snow in winter, the Green is plea≈øantne≈øs in Summer to walk in.

div.head: Riddle 13.
div.l: Though others wa≈øte, and ≈øpend their ≈øtore,
I have no means, yet am not poor,
By providence I ≈øtill am fed,
And have a Hou≈øe to hide my head.
div.p: Solution, It is a Snail with her Shell on her back.

div.head: Riddle 14.

figure.figDesc: a man unlocks a door as a dog(?) watches him

div.l: What force and ≈øtrength can ≈øcarce get thro‚ñ™
I with a touch you ≈øee can do;
A many in the ≈øtreet would lie,
Were I not to befriend them high.
div.p: Solution, It is a key, with which a man unlocks the Door to get into the hou≈øe.

div.head: Riddle 15.

figure.figDesc: a woman nursing a child on her lap

div.l: Little and big ≈øits on a ≈øtone,
Yet once they both of them was one;
Of tongues alike they do partake,
And yet but one of them can ≈øpeak.
div.p: Solution, It is a Mother ≈øitting with her Child in her lap.

div.head: Riddle 16.
div.l: We u≈øele≈øs are till took in hand,
And then we have a va≈øt Command;
No ≈øooner ≈øeen but we're ador'd,
And large Protections do afford;
We're coveted both far and near,
And for us bloody ≈øtrifes appear.
div.p: Solution, The≈øe are Scepters in the hands of Monarchs, and are much ≈øtrugled for.

div.head: Riddle XVII

figure.figDesc: a rooster, with a farmhouse in the background

div.l: A Bloody Crown upon my head,
In Plumes well arm'd I ≈øtrike a dread
In Noah's Ark our voice was heard.
I fight, but wealth I don't regard;
I precious Jewels ≈øpurn, and wou'd
For≈øake gold Mines for little food.
div.p: Solution, It is a Cock with Comb or Crown on his head, his Arms are his Spurs, &c.

div.head: Riddle XVIII.
div.l: I View the world in little ≈øpace,
Am always re≈øtle≈øs changing place;
No Food I eat, but by my power,
Procure what Millions do devour.
div.p: Solution, It is the Sun in perpetual Cour≈øe, who≈øe influence makes all things fruitful.

div.head: Riddle XIX.
div.l: Tho' ≈øen≈øe and motion in my ≈øelf there's none,
Yet tho≈øe that have, it metheir ≈øafe-guard own,

Dragging me over hills
‚Ä¢ nd mountains ≈øleep,
Whil≈øt I with railing ≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a Coil do keep,
in ≈øwifte≈øt Races and in Warlike deeds,
Without my help the brave≈øt ≈øeldom ≈øpeeds.
div.p: Solution, it is a Hor≈øe-≈øhooe, that accompany the Hor≈øe, and ≈øaves his Feet.

div.head: Riddle XX.
div.l: I ≈øpread my Wings to forreign Regions fly,
Over the Living pa≈øs, and yet have I
The Living in the Womb, I Thunder bear,
Combate with ≈øtorms, and Elements make war,
My going and returning makes ≈øome glad;
But Lo≈øing me, the merrie≈øt ≈øoon grow ≈øad.
div.p: Solution, it is a Ship, her Sails are here termed Wings her going over the Living, is the Fi≈øh, her men within her her Living, her thunder her Guns.
